__tnt.metering.compatibility = function(){
    var compatible = true;
    var status = "";
    
    /* this checks for compatibility with DOM storage */
    try{
        window.sessionStorage.setItem('__tnt.compatibility',true);
    }catch(e){
        compatible = false;
        status = "FAIL: setItem unsupported";
    };
    if(!compatible){
        __tnt.log(status);
    }
    return {'check':compatible,'status':status};

var bloxHasSubscription = false;
            var bloxServiceVerified = $.cookie('tncms-services-verified');

            /* if service not whitelisted check user service */
            if( bloxServiceVerified != 1 ){
                var bloxServiceIDs = [];
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(1122);
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(1298);
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(1299);
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(1300);
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(1913);
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(3821);
                
                    bloxServiceIDs.push(2997);
                
                if (__tnt.user.services){
                    var bloxUserServiceIDs = __tnt.user.services.replace('%2C',',').split(',');
                    $.each(bloxUserServiceIDs, function(index, value){
                        var serviceID = parseInt(value);
                        if( serviceID != 0 ){
                            if( $.inArray(serviceID, bloxServiceIDs) > -1 ){
                                bloxHasSubscription = true;
                                return false;
                            }
                        }else{
                            bloxHasSubscription = true;
                            return false;
                        }
                    });
                }
            /* service has been whitelisted */
            } else {
                bloxHasSubscription = true;
            }

            /* check for whitelists once per day */
            if( !bloxHasSubscription && !bloxServiceVerified && typeof userWhiteList != 'undefined' && $.isArray(userWhiteList) ) {
                $.getJSON("http://newtoncountytimes.com/_services/v1/client_ip_info",function(data){
                    /* create a range */
                    var dataRange = data.ip.split('.');
                    dataRange = dataRange[0]+'.'+dataRange[1]+'.'+dataRange[2];
                    if( jQuery.inArray(data.ip, userWhiteList) > -1 || jQuery.inArray(dataRange, userWhiteList) > -1 ){
                        /* white list machine */
                        $.cookie('tncms-service-validated', 1, { path:'/' });

                        bloxHasSubscription = true;
                    } else {
                        $.cookie('tncms-service-validated', 0, { path:'/', expires:1 });
                        
                        __tnt.metering.check();
                    }
                });

            /* no access */
            }else if( !bloxHasSubscription ){
                __tnt.metering.check();
            }
            
            if(bloxHasSubscription){
                $('.subscriber-only.encrypted-content').each(function(){
                    $(this).html(tncms.unscramble($(this).text()));
                    $(this).show();
                });
                $('.subscriber-hide').show();
            }

            // show main content div
            $('#site-container').show();

            // hide loading spinner
            $('.subscriber-load').hide();
        });

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 80;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 80) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 80);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>
</div>

<script src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/newtoncountytimes.com/shared-content/art/tncms/templates/libraries/flex/components/plugins/resources/scripts/jquery.calendario.7b513d925fce875220017f8d5a8055a0.js"></script>
<script>/*<![CDATA[*/ jQuery(document).ready(function($){
        var aChecked = [],
            urlParams = '/search/?l=25&unrolled=1&s=start_time&sd=asc&f=html',

            $wrapper = $( '#block-1487623 .fc-inner' ),
            $calendar = $( '#calendar-1487623' ),
            cal = $calendar.calendario({
                displayWeekAbbr: true,
                startIn: 0,
                onDayClick: function( $el, $contentEl, dateProperties ) {
                    window.location = $('#block-1487623 .url-template').attr('href') + urlParams + '&d1=' + $el.find('.fc-date').data('date') + '&d2=' + $el.find('.fc-date').data('date');
                }
            }),
            $month = $( '#block-1487623 .fc-month' ).html( cal.getMonthName() ),
            $year = $( '#block-1487623 .fc-year' ).html( cal.getYear() );


        $('#block-1487623 .fc-next').on('click', function() {
            cal.gotoNextMonth(updateMonthYear);
        });
        $('#block-1487623 .fc-prev').on('click', function() {
            cal.gotoPreviousMonth(updateMonthYear);
        });
        function updateMonthYear(){
            $month.html(cal.getMonthName());
            $year.html(cal.getYear());
            fetchDays();
        }
        function fetchDays(){
            if( aChecked.indexOf(cal.getYear() + '-' + cal.getMonth()) == -1 ){
                $.ajax({
                    type: 'GET',
                    dataType: 'json',
                    url: $('#block-1487623 .url-template').attr('href') + '/search/?year='+cal.getYear()+'&month='+cal.getMonth()+'&fmt=json',
                    cache: true,
                    success: function(data) {
                        $.each(data, function(index, value){
                            if(value.result.numEvents > 0){
                                sMonth = value.result.month.toString();
                                if(sMonth.length < 2){ sMonth = '0'+sMonth }
                                sDay = value.result.day.toString();
                                if(sDay.length < 2){ sDay = '0'+sDay }
                                sString = sMonth + '-' + sDay + '-' + value.result.year;

                                oNumEvents = {};

                                var iOneDot = 1,
                                    iTwoDots = 2,
                                    iThreeDots = 3;

                                oNumEvents[sString] = '<div class="fc-data-item">';
                                if( value.result.numEvents > 0 && value.result.numEvents < iOneDot+1 ){
                                    oNumEvents[sString] += '<i class="fa fa-circle"></i> ';
                                }else if( value.result.numEvents > iOneDot && value.result.numEvents < iTwoDots+1 ){
                                    oNumEvents[sString] += '<i class="fa fa-circle"></i> <i class="fa fa-circle"></i>';
                                }else if( value.result.numEvents > iTwoDots ){
                                    oNumEvents[sString] += '<i class="fa fa-circle"></i> <i class="fa fa-circle"></i> <i class="fa fa-circle"></i>';
                                }
                                oNumEvents[sString] += '</div>';

                                cal.setData(oNumEvents);
                            }
                        });

                        if( aChecked.indexOf(cal.getYear() + '-' + cal.getMonth()) == -1 ){
                            aChecked.push(cal.getYear() + '-' + cal.getMonth());
                        }
                    },
                    error: function(response) {
                        __tnt.log(response.status);
                    }
                });
            }
        }
        fetchDays();
    }); /*]]>*/</script>

            if (direction == 'down') {
            // Kill waypoint
            this.destroy();
                $(this.element).removeClass('empty');
                // Create and append ad iframe. Make sure this occurs only once
                var newIframe = infinityAd();
                if($(this.element).children().length <= 0) {
                    $(this.element).append(newIframe);
                }
            }
            }
        });

            // Infinity ad
            function infinityAd() {

                newIframe.scrolling = 'no';

      Rain showers this evening with clearing overnight. Low 32F. Winds WSW at 10 to 20 mph. Chance of rain 90%.

Aurelius/Cayuga

UPDATED: Boil water order announced for village of Cayuga, Aurelius Water District No. 3

  • Kelly Voll The Citizen
  • Jan 21, 2013
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Email
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Email
  • Print
  • Save

Unusually high winds and a fast freeze combined to cause a boil water order in the village of Cayuga and parts of Aurelius, according to the village's mayor.

The Cayuga County Health Department issued the order for municipal water users in the village of Cayuga and in Aurelius Water District No. 3 just before 6 p.m. Monday.

Those water customers should not drink, make ice, wash dishes, brush teeth or prepare food with the water unless they bring it to a boil, boil it for one minute and let it cool first, according to the health department.

Boiling the water will kill disease-causing organisms, which can include bacteria, viruses and parasites.

Village of Cayuga Mayor Helen Day explained that the high winds Saturday night and Sunday created large waves on Cayuga Lake that churned the lake so that sediment kicked up and interfered with the water system's intake pipe, where water is drawn from Cayuga Lake prior to purification.

"Our intake is extremely shallow," Day said. "Whenever the lake becomes turbid and it starts pulling the bottom up, our intake gets clogged."

Over the weekend, that is exactly what happened, Day said, leaving the lake brown from the eastern shore to the middle of the lake.

"The whole bottom was being churned up," she said.

The village was going to send a diver down to the intake to see how clogged it is, but the burst of cold air froze the lake and made an underwater investigation impossible.

"It's amazing how quickly it ices over," Day said. "The ice offers us protection (from the wind), but unfortunately we can't tell how much lake bottom and dirt is up around the intake and we can't get down there to clean."

Although the village typically struggles in winter due to ice melting and other weather factors, the one-two punch of the high winds and then the ice created a situation where the only purified water left was in the village water tank. Residents were being encouraged to control their water use, but now are advised to boil all tap water.

The boil water order will likely be in effect until next week, according to the village.

Day said residents are used to issues with the water purification plant and dealt with several boil water orders in the past. Day said the village is hoping to close the plant in 2014 and start buying water from the city of Auburn.

For information

For information on the boil water order, call the Village of Cayuga at 252-1707 or the Cayuga County Health Department at 253-1405.

LOUISVILLE, KY. (WDRB) -- A precautionary boil water advisory issued for part of Henryville, Ind., has been lifted, according to a news release from the Rural Membership Water Corporation.

The company issued the advisory on Jan. 18 for anyone living north of the fire department in Henryville.

The advisory was issued after a water main break at Hwy. 31 and Main Street.  It said that water customers should boil any water they consume for five minutes before using it.   

However, on Monday, the company issued a statement indicating that 18 water samples had been taken and no bacteria was discovered in any of them.

If anyone has any questions, they are asked to contact the Rural Membership Water Corporation at (812) 294-1481, Mon.–Fri. 8 a.m.-4:30 p.m.

<p>CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- West Virginia American Water has lifted a boil-water advisory for approximately 100 customers in the Pinch area of Kanawha County. The advisory was issued Friday for Pinch and Quick Road from Reunion Road and Pinchton Trail to Indian Lake Drive, Cottonwood Drive, Anderson Drive, Acorn Lane, Chansum Place and Greystone Estates following a water main break. Crews have since repaired that break, according to the water company.West Virginia American Water also lifted a boil-water advisory for 275 customers along Paint Creek Road in Kanawha County. The water company issued the advisory Friday for all West Virginia American Water customers in its Upper Kanawha Valley district following a boil water advisory. The town of Pratt, which provides the water for the system, issued the advisory.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"><div class="tncms-block" id="tncms-block-608361">

Chaffee temporarily shuts off water, boil order in effect

CHAFFEE, MO (KFVS) -

Water customers of the city of Chaffee will be without water Saturday for a couple of hours.

Police Chief Jim Chambers says the shut off is temporary while the problem is fixed.

Chambers says when the water comes back on, a boil water order is in effect for Chaffee water customers for the next three days.

        pKeywords = pByline.toLowerCase();
        pPresentationMode = pByline.toLowerCase();
        
        if(pKeywords.indexOf('nosale') >= 0 || pKeywords.indexOf('no-sale') >= 0)
        {
            showBuy = false;
        }

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p>The discovery of coliform bacteria in Sageville Elementary School’s water system has led to “overly cautious” precautionary measures, according to an official with the Iowa Department of Natural Resources.</p>
<p>“The school district is taking it seriously,” said Sue Miller, environmental specialist with the Iowa DNR.</p>
<p>Each week, Sageville’s water is tested at various points of the system. A positive test, confirmed with repeat testing, was recently discovered and isolated to one water fountain, according to an e-mail sent to families today.</p>
<div class="tnt-ads-container text-center ">
<div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-refreshable="true" id="fixed-big-ad-top-asset" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;">
<script>
                googletag.cmd.push(function() {
                    googletag.display('fixed-big-ad-top-asset');
                    
                });
            </script>
</div>
</div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>No E. coli was found. The type of coliform bacteria found at Sageville is not likely to cause illness.</p>
<p>“It’s just your typical bacteria that you find in soil,” Miller said.</p>
<p>The district has been working closely with the Iowa DNR, and has taken many steps above and beyond recommendations:</p>
<p>• The water to all drinking delivery points has been turned off.</p>
<p>• Fresh drinking water is being transported to Sageville from the district’s Central Kitchen.</p>
<div class="tnt-ads-container text-center ">
<div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-refreshable="true" id="fixed-big-ad-middle-asset" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;">
<script>
                googletag.cmd.push(function() {
                    googletag.display('fixed-big-ad-middle-asset');
                    
                });
            </script>
</div>
</div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><p>• Disposable paper products have been used for meals so dishes are not washed in the building’s water.</p>
<p>• Hand sanitizer and cleaning wipes are available for hand washing.</p>
<p>“We will continue to implement these steps until we have received a 100 percent positive test on all testing points at the school,” stated Bill Burkhart, manager of buildings and grounds with the district, in the e-mail. “We expect this to be confirmed by the end of the week.”</p>
<div class="tnt-ads-container text-center ">
<div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-refreshable="true" id="fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;">
<script>
                googletag.cmd.push(function() {
                    googletag.display('fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset');
                    
                });
            </script>
</div>
</div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>

        812 Pizza Co. bringing foodie culture to Georgetown</a></h3>
</div>
<div class="card-lead">
<p>GEORGETOWN — Beau Kerley owns two restaurants in Louisville, but when it comes to eating out, he often finds himself at the El Nopal in Georgetown, not just because he likes it, although he does, but because there aren't many dining options in his small town. </p>

<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Rural Membership Water Corp. has issued a boil water advisory for a portion of its customers in Henryville.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The advisory was issued due to a water main break at U.S. 31 and Main Street in Henryville.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":"cnhi\/newstribune","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/newsandtribune.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news\/clark_county"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-top-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Water customers on the north side of the system, which pertains to anyone living north of the fire department in Henryville, should boil any water consumed for five minutes before using.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The advisory will be in effect until at least Monday, Jan. 21.</p>

<div class="poll-panel panel">
<div class="panel-body">
<h4 class="">
<a href="/opinion/poll-should-clark-and-floyd-county-school-districts-ditch-the/poll_8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f.html">
        

        
        POLL: Should Clark and Floyd County school districts ditch the year-round academic calendar?</a></h4>
<div class="poll-content" id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989">
<div class="loading-poll hide-onload text-center"><i class="fa fa-spinner fa-2x fa-spin"></i></div>
<div class="show-onload">
<p>West Clark Community Schools has voted to move forward with a more traditional school calendar after six years of a year-round school schedule. Greater Clark is expected to do the same, and Clarksville Community and New Albany-Floyd County schools are considering making the move. A more traditional school calendar would mean students would start school the second week of August (instead of in July), have one week off for fall and spring breaks (instead of two), and dismiss for summer break before the Memorial Day holiday.</p>
<div class="hide-onload" id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989-your-vote-container">
<strong>You voted:</strong> <div id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989-your-vote"></div>
</div>
<div id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989-results" style="display: none;"></div>
<div id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989-container">
<form action="/opinion/poll-should-clark-and-floyd-county-school-districts-ditch-the/poll_8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f.html" id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989-form" method="post" role="form">
<div class="radio">
<label>
<input name="answer" title="Yes. Year-round was supposed to mean remediation time for students who have fallen behind, but that hasn't happened." type="radio" value="C7C79760-6300-0001-2D3F1D00AC80111B"/> Yes. Year-round was supposed to mean remediation time for students who have fallen behind, but that hasn't happened.
                                </label>
</div>
<div class="radio">
<label>
<input name="answer" title="No. The longer fall and spring breaks are perfect, and there's just enough of a summer break." type="radio" value="C7C79760-7D20-0001-FDBAEB0015271662"/> No. The longer fall and spring breaks are perfect, and there's just enough of a summer break.
                                </label>
</div>
<div class="radio">
<label>
<input name="answer" title="I'm indifferent, so long as all local school districts are on the same academic calendar." type="radio" value="C7C79760-9040-0001-FA30ABE0D130C610"/> I'm indifferent, so long as all local school districts are on the same academic calendar.
                                </label>
</div>
<button class="btn btn-success" type="submit">Vote</button>
<button class="btn btn-default" id="poll-8a5dc4ba-d6ce-11e7-b276-cba85abe572f-1133989-get-results">View Results</button>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });

<script type="text/javascript">var _ndnq = _ndnq || []; _ndnq.push(['embed']);</script>

<p>CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- West Virginia American Water has issued a boil-water advisory for approximately 275 customers along Paint Creek Road in Kanawha County. The advisory is in effect for all West Virginia American Water customers in its Upper Kanawha Valley district following a boil-water advisory that was issued by the Town of Pratt, which provides the water for this system.Customers in that area should boil their water for at least one full minute prior to use until further notice.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"><div class="tncms-block" id="tncms-block-608361">
<div class="tnt-ads-container text-center ">
<div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-refreshable="true" id="ad-608361" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;">
<script>
                googletag.cmd.push(function() {
                    googletag.display('ad-608361');
                    
                });
            </script>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>

<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">A boil-water notice for water customers in Bakerton and Watkins remained in effect Thursday evening after crews repaired a broken water line on Smith Road in Bakerton.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The West Carroll Township Water Authority said customers should boil all water used for cooking and drinking.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The authority will post a notice at the Bakerton post office when the boil-water notice has been lifted.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":"cnhi\/tribunedemocrat","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/tribdem.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news\/local_news"}' style="display:none;"></div>

</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"><strong>AYSO schedules registrations</strong></p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Greater Johnstown AYSO will hold in-person registration for new and past players for the spring soccer season.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Registrations will be held from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturday, 2 to 4 p.m. Jan. 26, 6 to 8 p.m. Feb. 7 and 2 to 4 p.m. Feb. 16 at The Grove in Westmont.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Fees are $55 for the first child, $45 for a second and $35 for any other children.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Past players also may register online at <a href="http://www.hilltopayso.org">www.hilltopayso.org</a>.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Online registrants should mail a printed copy of the completed registration form to AYSO in care of Westmont Hilltop Recreation, 1000 Edgehill Drive, Johnstown, Pa. 15905 and include registration fees and T-shirt size.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">All registrations must be postmarked by Feb. 22.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"><strong>St. Francis to hold open house Monday</strong></p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">St. Francis University in Loretto will host an open house for students and their families on Monday.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Registration will begin at 8:45 a.m. in the JFK Student Center.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The day will begin with an academic and activities fair, where prospective students will be able to speak to faculty representatives about more than 30 programs majors in business, sciences, health sciences, education and the humanities.</p>
<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The fair also will feature information on new programs including the public health major, the gaming/new media production concentration recently added to the computer science degree, and the newly created American sign language minor.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Participants can also find out about extracurricular activities, 22 NCAA Division I athletics teams, and a range of study abroad programs, including study at the university’s campus in Ambialet, France.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Parents will be able to participate in a presentation about the financial aid process. Financial aid representatives will be present to answer individual questions and talk about scholarships and grants available from the university.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">For more information or to register for the open house, call 866-DIAL-SFU, email <a href="mailto:admissions@francis.edu">admissions@francis.edu</a> or visit <a href="http://www.francis.edu">www.francis.edu</a>.</p>

<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"><strong>St. Vincent to host no till conference</strong></p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The 2013 Southwest Regional No Till Conference will be held from 9 a.m. to 2:45 p.m. Jan. 30 at the Fred Rogers Center at St. Vincent College in Latrobe.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Dairy farmer David Wolfskill will teach farmers how to be dollar and soil-wise in “Getting Top Yields with No Till” as keynote speaker at the interactive workshop for farmers.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Vendors will be on hand throughout the day to answer questions and show the latest in equipment and other tools and resources.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The cost is $30 through Sunday and $40 after Sunday.  </p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Parking is free, and the registration fee includes morning refreshments, lunch and meeting materials.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Information: <a href="http://www.wcdpa.com">www.wcdpa.com</a>.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"><a href="http://readercare.cnhionline.com/subscribe_pp.php?page=subscribe&location_id=tribunedemocrat">Click here to subscribe to The Tribune-Democrat print edition.</a></p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"><a href="http://tribdem.newspaperdirect.com/epaper/viewer.aspx">Click here to subscribe to The Tribune-Democrat e-edition.</a></p>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>

Sturgis boil-water advisory lifted

Thursday
Jan 17, 2013 at 5:10 PM Jan 17, 2013 at 10:07 PM

A boil-water advisory issued Jan. 11 for homes affected by the Sturgis water-main break has been lifted.

Affected areas:

East side of North Lakeview Avenue between Robin Hood Street and Marian Street.West side of North Lakeview Avenue between Buckingham Drive and Marian Street.Wilshire Park Drive between Canterbury Road and North Lakeview Avenue.

The 700 block of Devonshire Drive to Wilshire Park Drive.The Michigan Department of Environmental Quality requires water samples be collected and tested from the affected areas.

Water samples were collected Monday and Tuesday, and tests revealed no signs of coliform bacteria.

That means the drinking water quality meets the state of Michigan drinking water standards, so there is no need to continue to boil water for drinking or food preparation.

If you have any questions or concerns, call the Sturgis Department of Public Services.

WMU News

Boil water advisory over the weekend for some campus buildings

contact: Jeanne Baron
January 17, 2013 | WMU News

Boil water advisory for East Hall, Spindler Hall and Seelye Center

KALAMAZOO—Three occupied buildings on the Western Michigan University campus will be under a precautionary boil water advisory from the city of Kalamazoo from 2 p.m. Friday, Jan. 18, through at least 2 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 20. The buildings are East Hall, the Seelye Center and Spindler Hall.

The water in those buildings is scheduled to be turned off from 9 a.m. to about 2 p.m. Friday due to repair of a water main leak on Oakland Drive. Once the water to East Hall, the Seelye Center and Spindler Hall is turned back on at 2 p.m., the boil water advisory will be in effect until at least 2 p.m. Sunday.

WMU will provide bottled water to the three buildings, and is making additional arrangements to accommodate the needs of the buildings' occupants and visitors.

More information, including details on the implications of the boil water advisory, will be posted on the WMU website as they become available.

Archive for Wednesday, January 16, 2013

Boil water advisory in effect for water district in Jefferson County

  • Email
  • Print
  • Facebook
  • Tweet
  • Post a comment

By Shaun Hittle — Lawrence Journal-World

January 16, 2013

Advertisement

Jefferson County

Rural Water District #10 in Jefferson County.

A boil water advisory has been issued for the Rural Water District No. 10 public water system, which includes Lakeshore Estates in Jefferson County.

According to a news release issued by the Kansas Department of Health and Environment, the "city water supply has experienced a loss of pressure in the water system due to a water main break."

That allows the chance for contaminants to enter the water system, and chlorine levels could drop below levels needed to fight bacteria.

Those who receive their water from that district should:

• Boil it for one minute prior to drinking or food preparation, or use bottled water.

• Dispose of ice cubes and do not use ice from a freezer's automatic ice maker.

• Disinfect dishes and other food contact surfaces by immersion for at least one minute in clean tap water that contains one teaspoon of unscented household bleach per gallon of water.

• Water used for bathing does not generally need to be boiled. Supervision of children is necessary while bathing so that water is not ingested. Persons with cuts or severe rashes may wish to consult their physicians.

• If your tap water appears dirty, flush the water lines by letting the water run until it clears.

The media will be informed when the boil water advisory has been lifted. For more information, contact Pat Barnes at 785-608-3516 or 785-876-2639.

Murphy, NC issues "boil water" alert for all residents

Posted: Updated:
By Derrall Stalvey
Email
Connect
dstalvey@wrcbtv.com

MURHPY, NC (WRCB) -- The Town of Murphy has issued a Boil Water Advisory until further notice.  This means no water for internal consumption, i.e. drinking, brushing teeth, making drinks such as coffee or tea without boiling for at least one minute.

Douglas Clement, County Extension Director, said the town experienced another water main break Wednesday morning around 6:00 a.m. The main 16" water line broke causing them to lose most of the water in their reservoir thus causing a major drop in water pressure.

"Most of the businesses, however, are on the 'old' water line so they did have water, however, those businesses on the main water line have experienced a shortage of water this morning," Clements said. "The town is working on fixing the water line but it is uncertain how long this will take. In the meantime, they have shut off the water and are filling the reservoir at this time. "

The manhole where cite workers were going to place a temporary sewer pump washed away Tuesday night so another plan is being developed to replace that.

He noted the only issue that the Town of Andrews is having is sewer problems.  They are having uncontrollable discharge with the sewer because they are taking in more water than they can pump out.  Otherwise, within the city limits, Clement reports everything is fine.

Hyatts Creek continues to be closed due to flooding.  Also, there was a mudslide at the intersection of Bristol and Pisgah Road.  This is close to Carolina Rest Home so it may be a concern with having to run medical calls to that location. 

Beaver Creek was extremely high last night with water going over the culverts.

"One resident evacuated her home on Higdon Loop due to flooding.  She will be staying at a friend's house," Clement said Wednesday morning.

Hopewell Village is doing well.  All residents are staying and are able to use the port-a-johns.  They are on the "old" water line so they do have water.

One resident on Underwood Hill Road decided to evacuate due to flooding and they are staying at the Best Western in Murphy.  The Red Cross is assisting them.

The Cherokee County region had an additional .5" to 1" of rain overnight making the total amount of rainfall over a 48 hour period anywhere between 4.8" to 7.6".

City says “high” number of boil water advisories not unusual

By Mary King, Sunrise Anchor
Email
Connect
mking@wistv.com
COLUMBIA, SC (WIS) -

Less than a week ago, neighbors on Montgomery Avenue in the Rosewood neighborhood in Columbia were among the latest to be affected by a City water main break.

Mel Jenkins has lived on the street for 25 years, but says when a pipe burst last Thursday at 4:30am, that was a first.

"Columbia talks about it being a river city, we didn't expect them to bring a river to our neighborhood though," said Jenkins.

Jenkins said he watched water pour out for hours, and tons of sand from a neighbor's yard project was pushed down the street.

"One of the people said there was a least five feet of water down in their basement," said Jenkins. "I got a fair amount of damage, but some of our neighbors are pretty badly impacted by this."

The break in the Rosewood neighborhood is one of 10 water main breaks since December according to the City of Columbia. Since the start of the year, WIS has reported on several boil water advisories and water main breaks throughout the Midlands and in the City of Columbia's supply area.

City employees say the number of advisories has been high, but not unusual. 

"This time of year we see a lot more water main breaks than we tend to have because of the fluctuation of the temperature," said Joey Jaco, Director of Utilities for the City of Columbia.

Jaco said colder temperatures, change in pressure and change in system demand all can contribute to water line breaks.

"Since we've had these nice warm days, we haven't had any major breaks yet," said Jaco. "Hopefully we'll continue to see some warmer weather and that trend will stay with us."

Jaco said on average the City responds to 250 leaks or breaks every month, but the majority do not warrant a boil water advisory.

Weather aside, Jenkins believes there's a bigger issue.

"This is happening with frequency around the city, as we understand, so there's got to be some really good proactive plan to prevent this sort of thing from happening," he said.

Jaco said while the system is aged, the city is working proactively and has a $40 million infrastructure improvement budget for water lines.

"We're doing everything we can," said Jaco. "As far as, they're saying it's happening a lot right now, I think that's a good thing that we're communicating. That the communication's there."

The City has a third-party claims center that will assess the damage on Montgomery Avenue and work with homeowners like Jenkins. Jenkins said his biggest concern now is what's unseen.

"What we've got to do is get checking under the house and make sure that there's not damage under there, that there's not moisture under there which can translate into mold," he added.

Neighbors on Montgomery Avenue said the City was doing work on a fire hydrant the day before the break happened. We asked the city if the hydrant work could have been related to the break, and they say while there's always a possibility, they do not believe that was the case.

Jenkins told WIS he was not ever aware there was a boil water advisory issued. Jenkins said he was home during the break, but had not seen the news.

The City said when it comes to boil water advisories, it's not procedure for them to go door to door to notify residents. Officials say if it's a small area they will, but otherwise they utilize news outlets, a message system called Nixle, Facebook and Twitter.

"Unfortunately we can't always reach everyone when we send a Boil Water Advisory," said Jaco. "It's just an advisory, [that means] it's possible that something could have gotten in [the water]. It's not a boil water notice where we do know there's evidence of pathogens in the water."

Jaco said they are in the process of working on additional ways to notify residents in the event of a boil water advisory including the possible use reverse 911. But they always encourage anyone in an area where there's been a break or a change of water pressure to boil water. He said to date he's never heard of anyone becoming sick because of a City of Columbia water main break.

Milton has boil water advisory

Saturday, January 26, 2013 4:00 AM
Milton Water Company issued a boil-water advisory Friday due to a water main break.

Water customers on Peck Pike Road and any roads located off of Peck Pike Road - excluding Liberty Road - should bring all water to a rolling boil before using the water.

Although no contamination has been confirmed, residents are asked to boil water for three minutes and let it cool, or use bottled water, until further notice.

Home » Government » City Commission » Boil the water

Boil the water

Sturgis residents in a neighborhood in the city’s northeast quadrant are being advised to follow a boil-water advisory, following a water-main break last week.

The broken pipe was at the intersection of North Lakeview Avenue and Wilshire Drive.

More than a dozen basements were flooded as a result of the water-main break, which took place in the pre-dawn hours Friday, city officials said.

Water to the area was shut off while crews from the department of public works attempted to correct the problem. A drop in pressure during repair may have caused bacterial contamination in the water system, warranting a routine precautionary measure of boiling water and drinking bottled water.

Samples will be collected to determine whether water quality meets the state’s prescribed standards.

Boil water order issued for parts of Pope County

POPE COUNTY, IL (KFVS) -

Parts of Pope County, Illinois are under a boil water order due to a water main break.

According to Millstone Water District, customers from Delwood to the Saline County line along and both sides of Route 145 and all side-lines are under the boil order.

Boil water advisory in effect for part of downtown Wilm.

By: WECT Staff
Email
Connect
newsroom@wect.com

WILMINGTON, NC (WECT) – A precautionary boil water advisory has been issued by the Cape Fear Public Utility Authority for the 200 and 300 blocks of Front Street and 10 Walnut Street beginning at 11 p.m. Wednesday.

A news release from a CFPUA spokesperson reveals that crews are doing work on Wilmington's storm drain project, which will result in periods of low or no pressure for addresses affected through 7 a.m. Thursday.

Periods of low or no pressure resulting from the project increases the chances of back siphonage and bacteria getting into the water system. As a result, CFPUA officials advise that when water is restored, residents affected should boil their water for at least one full minute before using it for human consumption.

Only after water service is restored and the water quality is tested will CFPUA officials will cancel the advisory.

Keep checking WECT.com for updates as they become available.

Boil water order lifted for of DeSoto, Illinois

DESOTO, IL (KFVS) -

The boil water order for south Hickory Street in DeSoto has been lifted, according to the department of public works.

Superintendent Chris Lacy says repairs and necessary flushing and purification verification steps have been completed.

<meta content="TROY, N.C. -- Montgomery County officials say a Boil Water Advisory has ended following a "major equipment malfunction" at the county's water treatment plant."Based on the laboratory analysis of water samples collected throughout the county on (Tuesday), water users are hereby notified that it is no longer necessary to boil water used for human consumption," officials said Wednesday in a news release.Those who receive water service through the county's treatment facility may still "see some discoloration and experience air in the lines," but the characteristics do not represent any health risks, officials said.A Boil Water Advisory and “mandatory water conservation notice” were issued Sunday as officials informed residents of the malfunction at the plant.Officials said Monday they had completed repairs, but the advisory remained in effect as they continued to monitor water samples in an effort to guarantee there were no hazards." property="og:description"/>

<header class="entry-header">
<h1 class="entry-title">Boil Water Advisory lifted in Montgomery County</h1>
<div class="entry-meta clearfix">
<span class="posted-time">Posted 1:25 pm, January 23, 2013, by <a class="author url fn" href="http://myfox8.com/author/ryansullivanwghp/" rel="author" title="Posts by Ryan Sullivan">Ryan Sullivan</a>, </span><span class="updated-time">Updated at 01:26PM, January 23, 2013</span> </div>
<div class="entry-share">
<div class="sharedaddy sd-sharing-enabled"><div class="robots-nocontent sd-block sd-social sd-social-icon-text sd-sharing"><div class="sd-content"><ul><li class="share-facebook"><a class="share-facebook sd-button share-icon" data-shared="sharing-facebook-106471" href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/23/boil-water-advisory-lifted-in-montgomery-county/?share=facebook" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Share on Facebook"><span>Facebook</span></a></li><li class="share-twitter"><a class="share-twitter sd-button share-icon" data-shared="sharing-twitter-106471" href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/23/boil-water-advisory-lifted-in-montgomery-county/?share=twitter" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Click to share on Twitter"><span>Twitter</span></a></li><li class="share-google-plus-1"><a class="share-google-plus-1 sd-button share-icon" data-shared="sharing-google-106471" href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/23/boil-water-advisory-lifted-in-montgomery-county/?share=google-plus-1" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Click to share on Google+"><span>Google</span></a></li><li class="share-pinterest"><a class="share-pinterest sd-button share-icon" data-shared="sharing-pinterest-106471" href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/23/boil-water-advisory-lifted-in-montgomery-county/?share=pinterest" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Click to share on Pinterest"><span>Pinterest</span></a></li><li class="share-reddit"><a class="share-reddit sd-button share-icon" data-shared="" href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/23/boil-water-advisory-lifted-in-montgomery-county/?share=reddit" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Click to share on Reddit"><span>Reddit</span></a></li><li class="share-email"><a class="share-email sd-button share-icon" data-shared="" href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/23/boil-water-advisory-lifted-in-montgomery-county/?share=email" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Click to email"><span>Email</span></a></li><li class="share-end"></li></ul></div></div></div> </div>
</header>
<div class="row">
<div class="span8 span12-tablet border-right">
<img class="print-logo visible-print" src="https://s0.wp.com/wp-content/themes/vip/localtv-2/img/wghp/logo-gray.png"/>
<div class="article-archived">This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated. Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.</div> <article class="post-106471 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news" id="post-106471">
<div class="entry-content">
<div class="alignright wp-post-thumbnail">
<a data-keyboard="true" data-toggle="modal" href="#thumbnail-modal">
<img alt="" class=" wp-post-image" height="225" sizes="(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px" src="https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=400&h=225&crop=1" srcset="https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg 400w, https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=150&h=84&crop=1 150w, https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=300&h=169&crop=1 300w" width="400"/> </a>
</div>
<div class="modal hide fade" id="thumbnail-modal" tabindex="-1">
<div class="modal-header">
<button aria-hidden="true" class="close" data-dismiss="modal" type="button">×</button>
<h4 class="title">Boil Water Advisory lifted in Montgomery County</h4>
</div>
<div class="modal-body">
<img alt="" class="attachment-gallery-cover size-gallery-cover wp-post-image" height="225" sizes="(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px" src="https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=400" srcset="https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg 400w, https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=150 150w, https://localtvwghp.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/waterboarding.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=300 300w" width="400"/> <div class="lightbox-caption"></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>TROY, N.C. — Montgomery County officials say a Boil Water Advisory has ended following a “major equipment malfunction” at the county’s water treatment plant.</p>
<p>“Based on the laboratory analysis of water samples collected throughout the county on (Tuesday), water users are hereby notified that it is no longer necessary to boil water used for human consumption,” officials said Wednesday in a news release.</p>
<p>Those who receive water service through the county’s treatment facility may still “see some discoloration and experience air in the lines,” but the characteristics do not represent any health risks, officials said.</p>
<p>A <a href="http://www.montgomerycountync.com/online_forms/Water/boil%20water%20advisory_1-20-13.pdf">Boil Water Advisory</a> and “mandatory water conservation notice” were issued Sunday as officials informed residents of the malfunction at the plant.</p>
<p>Officials said Monday they had <a href="http://myfox8.com/2013/01/21/repairs-complete-at-water-treatment-plant-in-montgomery-county/">completed repairs</a>, but the advisory remained in effect as they continued to monitor water samples in an effort to guarantee there were no hazards.</p>
</div>

    Hulah water district lifts boil order, says water safe to drink

    10:08 AM, Jan 23, 2013
    Share Article

    A boil order issued last week for residents in four northeast Oklahoma communities has been lifted.

    Residents of Bowring, Oakridge, Whippoorwill Point and the area east of the Hulah Dam towards the Cross Bell Ranch were able to use their water as normally after Hulah Water District 20 on Tuesday morning rescinded the boil order placed Thursday due to a mechanical failure at its water treatment plant.

    An official told 2NEWS the district issued the order as a precautionary measure as the plant's filtration membranes last week became clogged, kicking off the plant's water pumps and reducing water pressure, increasing the potential for contaminated water.

    She told 2NEWS though the membranes are still on order and not due to be delivered until next week, the plant workers have been able to maintain water pressure sufficient to keep the water safe for consumption.

    Until the new parts arrive and are installed, plant workers will monitor the water quality to ensure it is safe to drink.
